column4: Why doesn't ubuntu have a good third party installer like windows or mac?
what do you mean by a third party installer?
I'm not sure what you mean by a third-party installer...
I mean, that I should be able to download random third party software that is for sale (costs money) double click on the application and run it/install it
the notion of having *everything* in a repository is anathema to a desktop operating system
lots of apps work that way... try Skype, for example.
you can click "download for Ubuntu", download the file, and literalyl double-click it.
it's just up to the software companies to actually use DEB packages.
you CAN, if they supply it for Ubuntu
no one's stopping companies from using DEB packages or writing their own installers
even open source softwrae that doesn't have a debian or ubuntu package manager *rarely* will upload .deb package
...then it's their problem.
but that's a little unfair to the companies too.  there's rpm, .deb and there's no binary guarantee that a compiled .deb or rpm will work on more than a single machine!
what do you mean? if the system's running Ubuntu, and they supply a DEB package that works on Ubuntu, it'll work on Ubuntu...
you're right they *could* build .deb files but those files may not work on debian if they work on ubuntu, or mepis, or insert other distribution here
so they can supply Ubuntu-specific ones. Ubuntu and Fedora, for example, may both be Linux, but they're both different operating systems.
I suppose so.  But one .deb that worked for ubuntu 8.04 might not work for 8.10
my big complaint is that until linux gets this right, we won't ever get applications like dreamweaver or other popular applications
and I *have* downloaded and compiled applications.  it's a suck process.  I need to use checkinstall and then make icons in the gnome menu myself
I suppose some aspects of what you're saying are true. I'm not sure how it could be fixed, though.
I don't know either.  It seems like klik and autopackage are the best options.  But the people with power to change this (people leading ubuntu) don't care to support and evangelize those solutions
